Bebop.profile: The furious, intellectual, and virtuosic revolution of the 1940s that became the foundation for all modern jazz. Bebop emphasized complex melodies over sophisticated chord progressions at blistering tempos, shifting jazz from dance music to a high art form for dedicated listeners.
data: Fast-moving, complex chord progressions (e.g., ii-V-I with substitutions), use of altered chords and extensions.
Blistering tempos, virtuosic and rhythmically complex solos, 'dropping bombs' with the bass drum.
Often based on standard song forms (like blues and 'I Got Rhythm' changes) but used as vehicles for extended improvisation.
Bebop.artists: Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk, Bud Powell
landmarkAlbums: Lester Young with the Oscar Peterson Trio

Hard Bop.profile: Evolving from bebop in the mid-1950s, Hard Bop re-injected the music with the earthy, soulful, and danceable influences of blues and gospel. With its strong backbeat, memorable melodies, and fiery solos, it became one of the most popular and enduring styles of the era.
data: Functional (ii-V-I), blues-based, gospel influences
Strong, driving swing feel, prominent drumming, danceable grooves
Standard forms (AABA, 12-bar blues), often with catchy, memorable heads
Hard Bop.artists: Art Blakey, Horace Silver, Clifford Brown, Lee Morgan
landmarkAlbums: The Blues and the Abstract Truth

Neo-Bop.profile: A powerful revival of the acoustic post-bop and hard bop traditions that emerged in the 1980s, led by the 'Young Lions.' It emphasized technical virtuosity and a deep reverence for the jazz tradition.
Neo-Bop.artists: Wynton Marsalis, Kenny Garrett, Joshua Redman

Soul Jazz.profile: A groove-oriented style that grew out of hard bop, Soul Jazz incorporates strong influences from blues, gospel, and rhythm and blues. It is characterized by its funky rhythms, catchy melodies, and often features the Hammond organ.
data: Simple, blues and gospel-based chord progressions, often using vamps.
Funky, danceable grooves with a strong backbeat.
Simple, memorable, riff-based melodies.
Soul Jazz.artists: Jimmy Smith, Cannonball Adderley, Stanley Turrentine, Lou Donaldson

Cool Jazz.profile: A reaction to the frenetic energy of bebop, Cool Jazz emerged in the late 1940s and 50s with a more relaxed, subdued, and lyrical approach. It often featured more complex, written arrangements, softer tones, and influences from classical music, creating a sound of understated elegance.
data: More complex, often drawing from classical harmony, less blues-centric
Relaxed, subtle pulse, lighter drumming, focus on understatement
Often employed complex, contrapuntal arrangements and non-standard forms
Cool Jazz.artists: Miles Davis (early), Dave Brubeck, Stan Getz, Gerry Mulligan

ECM Style Jazz.profile: Characterized by strong, folk-like melodies and atmospheric soundscapes, this style, largely defined by the ECM record label, favors lyrical improvisation and a pristine, spacious sound quality.
ECM Style Jazz.artists: Keith Jarrett, Jan Garbarek, Pat Metheny Group

Smooth Jazz.profile: A commercially-oriented evolution of jazz fusion, emphasizing polished production, melodic simplicity, and a relaxed, R&B-influenced groove.

Ambient Jazz.profile: A style that prioritizes texture and mood over traditional melody or rhythm, creating atmospheric soundscapes. It often incorporates electronic elements and was pioneered in works like Miles Davis's 'He Loved Him Madly'.

Modal Jazz.profile: A revolutionary approach pioneered in the late 1950s, Modal Jazz liberated improvisers by focusing on static scales (or modes) for long stretches, rather than rapidly changing chord progressions. This created a more spacious, meditative, and harmonically open soundscape, famously explored on Miles Davis's 'Kind of Blue'.
data: Static harmony, based on modes/scales rather than chord progressions
Floating, ambiguous pulse, less aggressive swing, focus on texture
Open-ended, simple structures, often just a single mode or vamp
Modal Jazz.artists: Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Bill Evans

Post-Bop.profile: The adventurous middle ground of the 1960s, Post-Bop took the harmonic complexity of bebop and the freedom of modal jazz and fused them with elements of the avant-garde. It's defined by its intricate original compositions, highly interactive rhythm sections, and 'controlled freedom,' where musicians stretch the boundaries of harmony and form without abandoning them completely.
data: Expanded functional harmony, non-functional chords, controlled dissonance
Highly interactive, fluid time, polyrhythms, elastic sense of swing
Modified standard forms, original compositions with complex, unique structures
Post-Bop.artists: Miles Davis's 2nd Quintet, Wayne Shorter, Herbie Hancock, Andrew Hill

Avant-Garde.profile: The 'Avant-Garde' describes a forward-thinking movement where musicians sought to challenge and expand the conventions of jazz. This often involved complex, unconventional compositions, unusual instrumentation, and a blend of structured sections with free improvisation, pushing the music into uncharted intellectual and textural territory.
data: Can include complex, atonal composed sections alongside free improvisation.
Ranges from free, pulseless textures to complex, composed rhythmic cycles.
Often features through-composed suites, blending written material with free improvisation.
Avant-Garde.artists: Eric Dolphy, Andrew Hill, Grachan Moncur III, Sun Ra
landmarkAlbums: The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady
The Shape of Jazz to Come
We Insist! Max Roach's Freedom Now Suite

Modern Creative.profile: A contemporary extension of the avant-garde, 'Modern Creative' is an umbrella term for music that freely incorporates elements from all eras of jazz, classical, and world music in highly original and often composed frameworks.

Third Stream.profile: A synthesis of jazz and classical music, 'Third Stream' seeks to blend the improvisational and rhythmic vitality of jazz with the compositional forms and instrumentation of the classical tradition.
Third Stream.artists: George Russell, Gil Evans, Anthony Davis

Free Jazz.profile: The most radical departure of the era, Free Jazz, pioneered by artists like Ornette Coleman, often abandoned preset chord changes, tempos, and forms altogether. The focus shifted to collective, spontaneous improvisation, prioritizing raw energy, texture, and pure sonic expression over traditional musical rules.
data: Abandons conventional chord progressions; focuses on texture and collective improvisation.
Often abandons a steady pulse; uses 'energy playing' and textural drumming.
Open forms, often based on a brief theme or motive, or completely improvised.
Free Jazz.artists: Ornette Coleman, Albert Ayler, Cecil Taylor, Pharoah Sanders

Spiritual Jazz.profile: A quest for transcendence through sound, Spiritual Jazz blends the modal and free explorations of John Coltrane with influences from African and Eastern music and a deep sense of religious or cosmic consciousness.
Spiritual Jazz.artists: John Coltrane, Alice Coltrane, Pharoah Sanders, Kamasi Washington

Jazz Fusion.profile: Emerging in the late 1960s, Jazz Fusion plugged jazz into the amplifier, incorporating the powerful rhythms of rock and funk, and the new textures of electric instruments like the Fender Rhodes piano and electric guitar. Led by Miles Davis, this movement created a dynamic, high-energy sound that would define the next decade of jazz.
data: Electric piano (Rhodes, Wurlitzer), synthesizers; post-bop harmony mixed with simpler rock/funk vamps.
Driving, straight-eighth rock and funk grooves, complex polyrhythms, high-energy drumming.
Extended, often through-composed forms, long open improvisations over vamps.
Jazz Fusion.artists: Miles Davis, Herbie Hancock, Weather Report, Mahavishnu Orchestra

Jazz-Funk.profile: A highly rhythmic and groove-oriented subgenre of fusion, Jazz-Funk emphasizes the deep pocket of funk and R&B, often featuring prominent electric bass lines and soulful horn arrangements.

Jazz-Rock.profile: A high-voltage fusion that combines the virtuosic improvisation of jazz with the volume, instrumentation, and raw power of rock music, often featuring complex time signatures and extended guitar solos.
Jazz-Rock.artists: The Mahavishnu Orchestra, John Zorn (Naked City)

Afro-Jazz.profile: A conscious reconnection with the music's African and Caribbean roots, Afro-Jazz integrates traditional rhythms, chants, and instrumentation into a modern jazz framework. It is often politically charged and celebratory.
data: Often uses modal or simple vamps derived from traditional folk melodies.
Incorporates African and Caribbean polyrhythms, heavy percussion.
Often features call-and-response themes and chant-based structures.
Afro-Jazz.artists: Johnny Dyani, Sons of Kemet, Shabaka and the Ancestors

Cape Jazz.profile: The distinct and vibrant jazz tradition of South Africa, blending the influence of American jazz with local musical styles like marabi, creating a sound that is both joyous and deeply resilient.
